html: merged!
I‚Äôm in favor.
if there are no objections, I‚Äôd like to push the ffi stuff to the main branch so I could work on non-ffi stuff without having to worry about merges
and pushed the bunch of random tests I‚Äôd built up during working on ffi
random test
The issue with trying to match the argument nesting is that something like {f32,i32,&u8} would also have to be nested for consistency, which I‚Äôd imagine gets frustrating.
It can do that, but you end up with a variable-length result.
also s/‚Ä¢bit._conv/‚Ä¢bit._cast/?
oh then there‚Äôs *&i32 which couldn‚Äôt spill each &i32 to a result item (but I could see being useful)

I‚Äôd have imagined that‚Äôd add a single result item, containing the 5-item array (or, in general, any & being present would result in the whole corresponding argument being a result item, with mutated parts mutated); Just adding a list for each & is simpler to implement though, so I‚Äôm fine with either
Also missing something like u64:~ to allow approximate conversion. I think it‚Äôs better to wait on this one as we may not want it at all.

In full generality it allows some crazy things like [5]&i32 for an array of 5 pointers to &i32, which should add 5 result elements. I don‚Äôt think it makes sense to implement this, but don‚Äôt see any value in explicitly disallowing it in the spec.
Added a spec here, which should fit CBQN‚Äôs intended behavior as I understand it.
Calling a ‚Ä¢FFI function seems to be missing a length check on the arguments?
oh, it not being an atom would be weird for ** - with :c8 there‚Äôs a reason for the two to be merged to a single array, but with just ** that‚Äôd be somewhat weirder
idea was that if BQN had system functions operating on character arrays as pointers, the character array would be the BQN form (not an atom, but I don‚Äôt think that matters)
I think *:c8 is much more explicit, so I‚Äôd rather * just not be supported if it doesn‚Äôt correspond to a BQN atom.
I‚Äôd consider opaque pointers to fall under expanding types.

The one other non-type feature I had in mind was C arguments that don‚Äôt come from BQN arguments. Two varieties might be useful: a constant value, and an uninitialized array with a specified length. I don‚Äôt know how to specify it (as you need both type and value), and it‚Äôs only a convenience/performance thing, so not very important.
(wait, puts has a trailing newline while fputs doesn‚Äôt? ‡≤†_‡≤†)

(for opaque pointers I‚Äôd personally rather have them be represented by a regular character array or something, and have some ‚Ä¢mem namespace with functions that can operate on those; I just really don‚Äôt like the sound of ** creating a list of namespaces)
besides opaque pointers, is there anything else important left to do besides expanding the types of things supported?
‚Ä¢FFI works on android aarch64 on termux! (at least for loading malloc from some random .so; should have some way to load functions not from an external .so file)

Pushed FFI-based filter, FFT, and resampling to BQNoise. Nothing should break if ‚Ä¢FFI isn‚Äôt available or the libraries can‚Äôt be loaded; FFTW just isn‚Äôt loaded anywhere until I figure out how I want to do that.
Okay, I just had real and imaginary parts swapped (imaginary comes first, really?).
FFTW is working! Getting different results versus BQN-based FFT and the J binding though; probably something to do with forward versus backward.
for properly doing out you‚Äôd want a way to explicitly allocate a persistent buffer
pushed *:c8 etc & allowing a:b in result
Right, so the C example is definitely only good for illustration.
and the lifetime of a &f64 ends when the function returns, so "*"‚Äø"id"‚Äø"&f64" would be use-after-free
well, a function returning * wouldn‚Äôt return a length, so pointer objects in general can‚Äôt rely on it
The pointer object needs to remember the length (shape?) so that C example is maybe not exact.

And then the most sound way to handle the out problem with FFTW would be to have a utility that converts an array to a pointer object (would be ‚Ä¢FFI "*"‚Äø"id"‚Äø"&f64" with a C function id returning it‚Äôs argument), and pass that in and convert it back to a BQN array when it‚Äôs finished being mutated.
As for plain *, I think we want a non-opaque namespace so it can have the reading and writing methods, which should probably be designed together with streams.
ah yeah that‚Äôs also a thing
Well, *:i32 would be a better way to write it.
u64 and pointers probably behave ~equally on x86-64, but not necessarily elsewhere
oh yeah still haven‚Äôt implemented the : thing for result
u64:i32 should work fine, right? It‚Äôs just that I get ‚ÄúUnimplemented result type‚Äù for it.
if going with a namespace, there‚Äôs the annoying thing that it‚Äôll be 2+field count allocations when constructing one
anyway, opaque pointers; what‚Äôs the design of those
cmovs tend to be kind of slow, and cmp/ja should be fused, so I‚Äôm not sure which of those is going to be faster.
(also huh clang does actually know to move the push rax to just before the call, but just decides to move it to the whole function for multiple calls)
godbolt
That i64 check is faster as (u64)(v+(1ULL<<53)) >= (2ULL<<53) I expect.
pushed u64/i64 arguments & check for exact values

State of FFTW: I have this code, which is stuck on being able to represent an opaque pointer (type plan). It also relies on ExecutePlan being able to modify out, which I guess will work since it‚Äôs an f64 pointer but is awful.
then there‚Äôs the question of 2^62 again
Yeah, but rounding is always part of float arithmetic.

huh, I don‚Äôt actually see slowdown for ""‚Äø"noopManyArgs"‚Äø"i8"‚Äø"i16"‚Äø"i32"‚Äø"u8"‚Äø"u16"‚Äø"u32"‚Äø"f32"‚Äø"f64" if the integer args are checked (but that invocation is also an immense 210ns)
(also, passing √∑3 to f32 is also technically loses precision)
‚Ä¶especially for arrays of structs, when those‚Äôll be a thing
Full checking, I think. These changes are on par with other kinds of overhead BQN adds. If you have a tight loop that really needs to be fast, just write it in C.

for returning u64, the bounds check is just movabs, cmp, and a jump, affects only some functions, and a max of one time per invocation. Checking whether a thing corresponding to an i32 is exactly an i32 is quite a bit more complicated, affects any function taking integer arguments, and once for each such arg

another question - how complete should error checking be on FFI function invocation? Some checks can be quite expensive (in the nanosecond scale of course), but ideally invocation should be as fast as possible
Fair.
and gonna go sleep without implementing u64 arguments
pushed name change & relative-to-source-file-ness
It is now.
was the final agreement on the name ‚Ä¢FFI?
Wow, this J FFTW script uses 6 (33 b.) 1 for constant 1<<6 instead of, you know, 2^6.
pushed allowing u64 result
Relative, same as ‚Ä¢file.Stuff.
so which should it be - relative to file or require absolute?
Okay, good (was definitely a ‚Äúwould expect‚Äù rather than a ‚Äúdid expect‚Äù; everything‚Äôs coming along pretty well).
ah that‚Äôs just incompleteness

One other thing, I‚Äôd expect a relative path to work but had to use ‚Ä¢file.Path. I guess I can understand not wanting ‚Ä¢LoadFFI to depend on the file it‚Äôs in, but it should at least give an error if you try to use a relative path in that case.
That‚Äôs what I was addressing.
(what about 2^62? It‚Äôs representable exactly as an f64, but it‚Äôs most likely not what would be meant)
Possibly with an error telling you to use u64:u64 (?) if you go past 2‚ãÜ53.
Yeah, I think so. Given how widespread using u64 for lengths is, I think we should probably be doing the same thing on inputs by default too.
so a lone returning u64 should be of the variety that checks if the value is representable exactly in an f64?
Oh, of course.
double gets returned by xmm, whereas u64 would be a GPR
Changing to u32 I do get 0.
The C return value should be a u64 of 0, but I set it to f64 and get 0.08456460987958714. Doesn‚Äôt make much sense to me.
I figured it out on this side just before you posted that of course.
Right result now!
pushed fix
ah yep &f32 is broken
This broke in j9 I guess. j8 is giving reasonable results.

Running now, and the length it sets is right, but the data converted from f32 looks wrong with numbers around 2‚ãÜ30. I can‚Äôt get my J version to return anything but 0 so I don‚Äôt know what the output should be.
No, although in this case I can ignore the result.
oh, retyping in general isn‚Äôt supported for the result
oh, i guess u64 isn‚Äôt supported for result
no
No u64:u64 or similar to convert to float though, right?
u64 does work if you have a type remapping (i.e. u64:c8)
Seems FFTW uses ints for everything, so I can probably get that to work.

Very low priority relative to having the functionality at all, of course. The thing I want most is soxr_oneshot() from sox‚Äôs (SOund eXchange) soxr.h for resampling, and that‚Äôs stuck on missing support for u64 and &u64.

Got it working with the filter test! Only 8x faster than plain BQN, which is kind of amazing. Repeating in C versus BQN, it looks like there‚Äôs about a 25% overhead, even when I time with ‚çü10 so it should be working on refcount-1 data after the first call.
aand that‚Äôs now pushed

yay
Looks right to me. >ùï® feels like the more natural order to me, although either makes sense.
so "&"‚Äø"fn"‚Äø">i32"‚Äø"ùï®>&i32" for taking a number as the right arg, integer array as left, and returning the mutated integer array
Plain & is a good indicator for the second thing, I think.
I think that‚Äôs the best default. The result can be used to say ‚Äúalways use a list‚Äù or ‚Äúvoid but don‚Äôt make a list‚Äù as a compatible extension.

for result I still think it‚Äôd be fine if with no mutable args you just got the result, and otherwise it‚Äôs a list, the first element being the result (or not present if void); leads to the funky situation that a void function with a single mutable arg returns a 1-element list, but I think that‚Äôs fine
after some thought, I think I‚Äôd be fine with needing to explicitly denote then an argument is the whole of ùï®/ùï©, defaulting to a list. Result is still problematic though
(34% of the time in that is spent in libffi, so that gives a minimum of 11000ms; of course everything anywhere near fast would be JITted)

yeah the current setup isn‚Äôt gonna beat much in speed. plusOne ‚Üê "local/lib.so" ‚Ä¢LoadFFI "i32"‚Äø"plusone"‚Äø"i32" and then )t PlusOne‚àò‚ãà‚çü500000000 0 gives 31.3s, aka 31300ms, worse than everything except Go and ‚Äúdart scoped‚Äù whatever that is (assuming my processor performs similarly to the author‚Äôs, which isn‚Äôt a good assumption but ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø)
benchmarks for other languages: https://github.com/dyu/ffi-overhead
using -Wl,--dynamic-list=syms where syms is a file of the to-be-exported symbols instead brings text down to 1115388
oh, 61KB of the binary size increase comes from -rdynamic
Definitely all right.

pretty fast actually, considering speed wasn‚Äôt my consideration for the loading part
So you need to load like 5k functions to get to 1ms overhead? That‚Äôs fine.
it seems to always return the same thing, and thus takes ~200ns

What‚Äôs the performance impact of reloading from the filename multiple times? Inclined to say it won‚Äôt be enough to matter since you only need to load each function once, but if scanning is hard then maybe that‚Äôs not true.
It‚Äôs a question of whether we want an ‚Ä¢ffi namespace. In theory you could want some header parsing stuff too, but that‚Äôs probably best handled by a BQN library.
(and there‚Äôs still the whole question of whether the left arg should be just a path to the .so, or whether there should be some shared object object)
so, ‚Ä¢FFI or ‚Ä¢FFILoad?
‚Ä¶and fixed
also it seems i‚Äôve broken :-things
the name was super temporary
I don‚Äôt see an issue with plain ‚Ä¢FFI for the name, but ‚Ä¢FFIload seems better than ‚Ä¢LoadFFI because it makes it clear that the FFI is the thing used for loading and not the thing being loaded.
anyways here‚Äôs the thing
Another thing to do would be to have inner versions of bqn_make*Arr that take the size as input, and compute it once on the outside.

 3618 genObj
 2699 buildObj

the largest new function is 3.6KB, the function to convert a BQN object to a C one. Then, at 2.7KB, is the one for converting back to BQN
I doubt it‚Äôs an improvement here, but for some loops maybe.
Unrolling to split one loop branch into several of them that are easier to predict is probably justifiable.
actually, seems a RARE makes it just unroll, but not go SIMD
and #pragma clang loop unroll(disable) is a #pragma for some moronic reason so I can‚Äôt add it in a #define
doesn‚Äôt work iirc
Is there a good way to indicate that a loop should be short? Seems like adding RARE on the condition could.
text 1176207‚Üí1173455; 3KB less
‚Ä¶or add if (the thing already written) thrM("Size too large"); around it
So you could fix it with some non-inlined versions of those probably.
hm, the bqn_make*Arr impls, while using memcpy for the elements, use manual loops for taking the product of the size_t* and convert it to to a usz*, and those get unrolled to oblivion
that results in a 9000-line file
-D should include sections that -d ignores?
objdump -d obj/def_o3n_si/ffi.o results in a 7000-line file, which is reasonable-ish
Should be easy enough to put ffi.o through objdump and figure out what‚Äôs there?
And I don‚Äôt see anything in ffi.h that would take up binary space.
ffi.o by itself is 60KB

I‚Äôd assume so
Yeah, that‚Äôs a little worrying. libffi is dynamically linked?
don‚Äôt know why the binary is 8.6% bigger though
Nice.
and mutation
report of progress
I guess u64:u64 giving an error and telling you the two options is actually kind of useful, since neither option is very good. Depends on how knowledgeable we expect FFI users to be.
I‚Äôd definitely go for crash over inaccuracy, by default at least
(Crash as in BQN error, which presumably nobody‚Äôs going to handle)

Although in the cases where you want to convert, a crash is probably worse than inaccuracy? We could allow both with u64:~u64 and u64:!u64, probably more complexity than it‚Äôs worth. But there should definitely be a u64:u64 that does some default conversion.
I think it would be better to just not allow bare u64. If we do allow it, require the f64 conversion to be exact.
should that include u64, losing information?
(then there‚Äôs still the whole question of long which we will need to support at some point, and having some ability to have the BQN side always convert it to 64-bit would be good)
Could have another character so $u64:c8 means it‚Äôs a list.
Yeah, that was the idea.
though i guess f32:i32 could be useful to not
I was imagining it‚Äôd always make a list
You could check the widths to decide whether to make it a list, but that sounds like an annoying inconsistency.
According to what I wrote u64:c8 would mean the u64 corresponds to one BQN c8. To make a list, what you‚Äôd want is more like [1]u64:c8.
By default I think you should just convert a C number to a BQN number; the fact that there‚Äôs no optimized representation for some types is irrelevant.
(and what‚Äôs ‚Äúincomplete‚Äù about u64:c8?)
and f32 too I guess; makes most sense as an f64 array, but that‚Äôs also wasteful and makes :x have to have a different storage mechanism
how are unsigned types represented? especially u32, which can fit in losslessly fit in an f64, but that‚Äôd mean an array of them needs to use an f64 array
that feels like just too special additional syntax to learn for a marginally useful thing
yeah
That‚Äôs much weirder because there‚Äôs no single place to put it in the list case.
having just < for ‚Äúthis is a list‚Äù for both result & (optionally) input would work imo
I guess I wouldn‚Äôt be averse to doing the opposite of that either.
Could put an > on the function name to say ‚Äúnothing is a list‚Äù and get it down to one.
You‚Äôre down to the two >s in that case then.
oh i‚Äôm definitely for manually choosing ùï® vs ùï©
Besides, which argument is ùï® and which is ùï©? There‚Äôs no way for that not to be confusing if ‚Ä¢FFI forces one mapping or the other on you.
I don‚Äôt like it being smart, but I would kinda like it to not be annoying

well, if you originally took as a non-list before (which I would literally 100% of the time), it wouldn‚Äôt help you besides letting you know that you need to change it (but that‚Äôs really not hard to know by yourself)
I really don‚Äôt like the lowest-level interface being ‚Äúsmart‚Äù like this and forcing you to build the consistent thing as an extra layer on top.
And it‚Äôs one more thing to change if you do the normal C thing and add an argument to your function.
Consistency. If you want to take a list then having to write ‚äë or ¬¥ based on number of arguments is really annoying.
I also don‚Äôt really see what being explicit with when a thing is the whole input/output gives you
so two chars saved, uglier code gotten, and a pointless allocation
You do also have the option of sticking ‚ãà after the whole thing.
and having my preference result in 3 extra chars is pretty ugly
well, I will want to then
Disagree there.
(assuming you do want to spread those on ùï® and ùï©, which you very likely will)
And many of the cases where it would happen just have a prototype repeated a lot, in which case you‚Äôd want to make that a constant regardless.
well, single-argument and two-argument. I‚Äôd guess those two make up a pretty good portion of all functions.
If you have a lot of single-argument functions you can write a wrapper around ‚Ä¢FFI. My guess is this isn‚Äôt too common.
Usually 1‚Üì covers the last one, but conversion could be expensive on rare occasions.
all single-argument functions having a forced > on the single argument isn‚Äôt too nice
Like #type for ‚Äúresult ignored; mutable pointer used‚Äù, <type for ‚Äúresult is a list‚Äù, <#type for ‚Äúresult is a list but the C result isn‚Äôt in it‚Äù.
And an explicit marker on the result type to tell you that there are arguments contributing instead/too is probably a good thing.
We might want to do the result differently, yes.
The very worst case is ">a"‚Äø"fn"‚Äø">a"‚Äø">ùï®a", and I don‚Äôt see that as particularly painful.
outside of things that mutate array arguments (which are rare), you‚Äôd always have one result though
I‚Äôd prefer it to always be a list by default. There‚Äôs not a lot of difference between one argument and a few in C, and I think I‚Äôd run into the inconsistency a lot.
the alternatives are pretty much all either ugly or don‚Äôt provide an actual single place defining the case
I‚Äôd be fine with whole argument/result vs list of such being implicit from the number of corresponding things
I like * for constant pointers and & for mutable ones, but the last one or two would require some extra symbols (last one could also be indicated with > plus some ignore symbol on the C result type).

Then you have a few possibilities for pointers with regards to the result:

  • Assume constant; no result
  • Mutable; ignore result
  • Mutable and put result into the result list
  • Mutable and make result the whole result
For a mutable pointer, the > would apply to the argument, because generally you have the result value preventing it from working on the result.

I think sticking a ùï® in front of an argument‚Äôs type to say it comes from ùï®, as opposed to default ùï©, is fine. I also like the idea of a > or some other symbol in front of a value to say it doesn‚Äôt go in a list. That would only be valid if there‚Äôs no other value associated to the same thing.
We might also want to ignore the result, or maybe to use a constant for a C argument (set a number to 0 or something).
A mutable pointer argument can be part of both an argument and the result. Otherwise, C arguments come from one BQN argument, and the result goes to the result.

Going back to this, the most general information we want is, for each of ùï®, ùï©, and the result, which C-side values go into them, and if there‚Äôs exactly one, whether it should be a list. I think not allowing ùï® if it would be a length-0 list is fine; that can be fixed with ‚àò‚ä¢.
For pointers we‚Äôre going to have more work to do in a lot of cases.

i‚Äôm thinking about having two separate FFI modes, toggleable at compile-time (along with a 3rd option of no FFI of course) - one only supporting "a"‚Äø"fn"‚Äø"a" and "a"‚Äø"fn"‚Äø"a"‚Äø"a" or something and requiring just dlfcn.h, and the full(er) one, using libffi

about u64:a - I think binding the FFI to a specific bit width for BQN objects isn‚Äôt good; while 128-bit pointers won‚Äôt be a worry for a long time, CHERI already exists (with 128-bit pointers) and apparently has a libffi impl, and 32-bit systems shouldn‚Äôt necessarily be forced to waste 32 bits if they don‚Äôt do tagging. We can put an array length on the BQN side, for example *i64:[8]i8 to convert to a matrix with cells of 8 elements. Implicit length, like *i64:[]i8, would indicate that the part to the right (i8 here) has to divide the element size on the left exactly, and it picks a length so an element is one row.

I don‚Äôt think structs end up being that bad. You have two options: treat the whole thing as opaque and cast (maybe if you read a chunk of bytes from a file), or split up the input as a list (could have separate depth/rank options) and recurse.

Deal with in what way? I think the full version of the type specification should let you specify how to translate a BQN array, pretty much like the input or output of ‚Ä¢bit._cast.

model 1 is two things, correct?

  • Being able to interact with BQN from a language that speaks C (cdefs)
  • Being able to interact with a language that speaks C from BQN (‚Ä¢FFI)
(and ofc it gets complicated quickly if you have structs)
I just don‚Äôt really like model 1 needing to deal with int/long/long long/int[n]_t without actually doing that in C which actually knows what those mean
it‚Äôs true that passing full BQN objects could be just another ‚Äúpassable object‚Äù type to model 1; the two could probably be merged at some point, but that‚Äôd require both being pretty stable

Some features for second model would also be useful for something like a UI framework that maintains its own state. You‚Äôd like to be able to automatically free something when the BQN-side references disappear.

dzaima‚Äôs identified two major use cases, while I‚Äôd been almost entirely interested in just the first. It‚Äôs my opinion that they can be combined in the same interface, where the second adds features to a basic model of being able to call C functions with BQN inputs and outputs.

  • Calling an existing C library, or writing a ‚Äúpure C‚Äù library that doesn‚Äôt relate to BQN at all.
  • Writing a library to interface with BQN, which might have bidirectional inputs and outputs, or maintain references or mutable state.
